{{Infobox person | name = Miles O'Brien | image = Miles O'Brien 2014.jpg | caption = O'Brien in 2014 | birthname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|6|9|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Detroit, Michigan]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | education = Attended [[Georgetown University]] | children = 2 | residence = [[Chevy Chase, Maryland]] | occupation = Journalist | website = {{URL|http://www.milesobrien.com}} }} '''Miles O'Brien''' (born June 9, 1959) is an independent American [[broadcast journalism|broadcast news]] journalist specializing in science, technology, and [[aerospace]] who has been serving as national science correspondent for ''[[PBS NewsHour]]'' since 2010.
==Early life== Born in [[Detroit]] and raised in [[Grosse Pointe Farms, Michigan]], O’Brien attended [[Georgetown University]]. In 1982, he was offered and accepted his first broadcasting position with [[WRC-TV]] in Washington, DC. He was later a reporter and anchor at TV stations in Boston, Massachusetts; Tampa, Florida; Albany, New York; and St. Joseph, Missouri. O’Brien joined [[CNN]] in 1992.
He is a third-generation [[general aviation]] pilot. His father, a private pilot, shared his love of flying with him at an early age.<ref>{{cite news|last=Muntean|first=Pete|title=ON AIR An Interview With Newsman Miles O'Brien|url=http://www.pilotmag.com/departments10|accessdate=17 August 2012|newspaper=Pilot Magazine|date=July–August 2010}}</ref> His first flights were in small [[Cessna]]s and [[Piper Aircraft|Pipers]] rented by his father. O'Brien's paternal and maternal grandfathers were also both pilots.
== CNN correspondent and anchor ==
While with CNN in Atlanta and New York, O’Brien served as CNN’s science, space, aviation technology, and environment correspondent. He anchored programs including ''Science and Technology Week,'' ''[[Headline News]],'' ''Primetime,'' ''Live From…(CNN),'' and CNN ''[[American Morning]].''
O’Brien covered all aspects of the [[United States space program]] for CNN including reports on the [[Hubble Space Telescope]], the shuttle dockings at Mir, the first space station launch from [[Kazakhstan]], [[John Glenn]]’s return to space (with broadcast journalist [[Walter Cronkite]]), landings on Mars, the winning of the Ansari X-Prize, and the tragic loss of the [[Space Shuttle Columbia]] and its crew, a story he told to the world in a 16-hour marathon of live coverage. After years of negotiations, [[NASA]] had signed an agreement with CNN that, if not for the disaster, would have made O’Brien the first journalist to fly on a space shuttle. O’Brien followed the investigation and successful return to flight.
In 2000, O’Brien produced, shot and wrote a one-hour documentary on the process of readying a space shuttle for flight: "Terminal Count: What it Takes to Make the Space Shuttle Fly," which aired in May 2001.
A private pilot since 1988, O’Brien also reported extensively on civil aviation issues and crash investigations. O'Brien reported the airliner crashes of [[US Airways Flight 427]], [[ValuJet 592]], [[TWA 800]], [[EgyptAir 990]], [[American Airlines 587]], [[Comair 5191]], [[John F. Kennedy, Jr.]], [[Payne Stewart]], [[Paul Wellstone]], the C-150 incursion into the Washington DC Air Defense Identification Zone, and the [[Cory Lidle]] crash in Manhattan. In the wake of the [[September 11 attacks]], O'Brien provided viewers radar tracks of the hijacked flights while the twin towers were still standing. During the [[Afghanistan]] and [[Iraq]] invasions, he, along with various retired generals, reported on military aviation techniques and strategy.
His coverage of non-aerospace topics included anchoring ''[[The Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer|The Situation Room]],'' covering the [[November 2008 Mumbai attacks|terrorist attack in Mumbai]] on the [[Oberoi Trident]] and [[Taj Mahal Palace & Tower|Taj Mahal]] hotels, as well as several other locations. He also covered [[Hurricane Katrina]] for several weeks, anchoring CNN's [[Peabody Award|Peabody]] and [[Dupont Awards|Dupont Award]]-winning coverage.
O’Brien left CNN in December 2008. He was rehired by CNN as an aviation analyst in March, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Too Much Coverage of Missing Plane?; Interview with Liz Wahl |url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1403/23/rs.01.html |website=CNN |publisher=CNN |accessdate=26 June 2016 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140324035344/http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1403/23/rs.01.html |archivedate=24 March 2014 |date=23 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Independent correspondent/journalist==
After leaving CNN, O’Brien formed Miles O’Brien Productions, LLC in Washington, DC. Through this independent company, O’Brien creates stories for numerous outlets including [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]], [[Science Channel|Discovery Science (TV channel)]], [[National Science Foundation]], Spaceflightnow.com, and corporate clients. One of his most notable series productions for PBS was "Blueprint America"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/blueprintamerica/|title=Blueprint America - PBS|work=Blueprint America|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> that dealt with rebuilding American mass transit infrastructure.
O’Brien joined [https://web.archive.org/web/20100605120509/http://trueslant.com/milesobrien/ "True/Slant"] as a blogger in 2009. He co-founded the Spaceflight Now podcast, "This Week in Space" in 2009, and hosted shows until the shuttles’ retirement in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spaceflightnow.com/|title=Spaceflight Now - The leading source for online space news|work=spaceflightnow.com|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref>
Starting in 2009, O’Brien joined the [[National Science Foundation]] as a correspondent for the “Science Nation” series,<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/news/special_reports/science_nation/producers/obrien.jsp|title=US NSF - Meet the Producers: Miles O'Brien|work=nsf.gov|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> and joined the PBS ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' produced by [[WGBH-TV]] Boston, as a writer and correspondent.
He worked on the ''Frontline'' documentary, "Flying Cheap"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/flyingcheap/|title=Flying Cheap - FRONTLINE - PBS|work=pbs.org|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> which aired on the one-year anniversary of the [[Colgan Air Flight 3407|Colgan Air plane crash]] in Buffalo, NY. The highly acclaimed documentary featured former [[Colgan Air]] pilots revealing shocking details about some attempts to keep underpaid pilots flying beyond legal limits.
In 2010, O'Brien became a ''[[PBS NewsHour]]'' science correspondent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/author/mobrien/|title=Miles O'Brien|work=PBS NewsHour|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref>
In 2013, O’Brien produced and directed “Mind of a Rampage Killer”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/body/mind-rampage-killer.html|title=NOVA - Mind of a Rampage Killer|work=pbs.org|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> and “Manhunt: Boston Bombers”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/tech/manhunt-boston-bombers.html|title=NOVA - Manhunt—Boston Bombers|work=pbs.org|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> and “Megastorm Aftermath”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/earth/megastorm-aftermath.html|title=NOVA - Megastorm Aftermath|work=pbs.org|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> for PBS' ''[[Nova (TV series)|Nova]].'' In 2014, he produced and narrated "Why Planes Vanish?" for NOVA, adapted from "Where is Flight MH370" from the [[BBC]] science program [[Horizon]]. He also narrated a recent view after the Fukushima disaster on a new episode of [[Nova]].
==Career timeline== *1981–82: [[WRC-TV]] assignment editor/production assistant in Washington, DC *1983: [[KQTV]] anchor/reporter/producer/photographer/editor in St. Joseph, MO *1983–84: [[WNYT (TV)]] anchor/reporter/producer in Albany, NY *1984–86: [[WTSP]]-TV special segment reporter/producer in Tampa/St. Petersburg, FL *1986–91: [[WHDH (TV)]] general assignment reporter/anchor in Boston, MA *1991–92: ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' freelance producer/reporter/anchor in Boston, MA *1992–2008: [[CNN]] space/aviation correspondent; “Science and Technology Week” anchor; “Science and Technology” correspondent/anchor; “CNN Live From” anchor, “CNN Saturday/Sunday Morning” anchor; “CNN Headline News Prime” anchor; “CNN American Morning” anchor in Atlanta, GA and New York, NY *2008–present: owner Miles O’Brien Productions, LLC in Washington, DC serving as correspondent/writer for [[Science Channel|Discovery Science]] “Innovation Nation” series; [[WNET]] “Blueprint America” series; and video productions/moderation of events for clients including [[McAfee]], SAP, [[X-Prize Foundation]], Medco, Astrogenetix, and the [[Rocket Racing League]] *2009–11: co-founder/host Spaceflight Now shuttle webcasts from Florida *2009–11: chairman Education and Public Outreach Committee of [[NASA]] Advisory Council<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/offices/nac/members/Obrien-bio.html|title=NASA - Miles O'Brien|work=nasa.gov|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> in Washington, DC *2009–present: [[PBS]] ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' writer/correspondent for “Flying Cheap,” “Flying Cheaper,” “Nuclear Aftershocks,” and “Dollars and Dentists” in Boston, MA *2009–present: [[National Science Foundation]] correspondent for “Science Nation”<ref name=autogenerated2 /> series in Washington, DC *2010–present: ''[[PBS NewsHour]]''<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/aboutus/bio_obrien.html PBS NewsHour About Us]</ref> science correspondent/producer in Washington, DC *2013–present: [[PBS]] ''[[Nova (TV series)|Nova]]'' producer/director “Mind of a Rampage Killer,” “Manhunt: Boston Bombers,” and “Megastorm Aftermath” in Boston, MA *2014–present: [[CNN]] ''aviation analyst
==Personal life==
O'Brien resides in [[Chevy Chase, Maryland]]. He has a son, Miles, and a daughter, Connery.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/29892416@N06/7056431067/in/photolist-bKy47B|title=MIDN O'Brien and Connery|work=Flickr|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref>
An instrument-rated pilot with about 2,000 hours pilot-in-command time, O'Brien owns a [[Cirrus SR22]], which he often flies on assignments. His other interests include running, [[Mountain biking|mountain]] and [[Road cycling|road biking]], swimming, waterskiing, [[scuba diving]], sailing, and [[carpentry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/lifestyle/health/pbs-correspondent-miles-obrien-has-arm-amputated|title=PBS correspondent Miles O'Brien has arm amputated|work=7NEWS|accessdate=13 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213041819/http://www.thedenverchannel.com/lifestyle/health/pbs-correspondent-miles-obrien-has-arm-amputated|archivedate=13 February 2015|df=}}</ref>
In February, 2014, O'Brien was injured when a [[Pelican case]] filled with television equipment fell on his left forearm, causing acute [[compartment syndrome]] and resulting in the amputation of his left arm above the elbow.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://milesobrien.com/?p=3640|title=Miles O'Brien - Journalist|work=milesobrien.com|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/lifestyle/health/pbs-correspondent-miles-obrien-has-arm-amputated |title=PBS correspondent Miles O'Brien has arm amputated |work=7NEWS |accessdate=1 January 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302071546/http://www.thedenverchannel.com/lifestyle/health/pbs-correspondent-miles-obrien-has-arm-amputated |archivedate=2 March 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Affiliations== [[File:MilesO'BrienRNASAjsc2013e026538.jpg|thumb|right|Miles O'Brien at 2013 RNASA gala]]
O'Brien is on the boards of the Challenger Center for Space Science Education,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.challenger.org/blog/staff/board-of-directors/|title=Home - Challenger.org - Inspiring. Exploring. Learning. It's our Mission.|work=Challenger.org|accessdate=13 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702235737/http://www.challenger.org/blog/staff/board-of-directors/|archivedate=2 July 2014|df=}}</ref> the Council for the Advancement of Science Writing, [[LessCancer.org]], and the Rotary National Award for Space Achievement Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rnasa.org/board_of_advisors.html|title=Rotary National Award for Space Achievement (RNASA) - Board of Advisors|work=rnasa.org|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref>
From 2009 to 2011, O'Brien served as chairman of the NASA Advisory Council (NAC)'s Education and Outreach Committee and advised the NASA Administrator on mass communication strategies. He rejoined the NAC <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/offices/nac/home/|title=NASA Advisory Council (NAC)|work=NASA|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> in April 2014 to advise NASA's senior leadership on challenges and solutions facing the agency as it unfolds a new era of exploration.
He is a member of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aopa.org/ |title=General Aviation's largest, most influential association in the world - AOPA |work=aopa.org |accessdate=13 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100816213310/http://www.aopa.org/ |archivedate=16 August 2010 |df= }}</ref> (since 1988), the [[American Federation of Television and Radio Artists]] (since 1982), the Experimental Aircraft Association<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eaa.org/|title=EAA - Experimental Aircraft Association - Oshkosh, Wisconsin|work=eaa.org|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> (since 2007), and the Writers’ Guild of America (since 2011).
In 2014, O'Brien joined the Board of the Amputee Coalition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amputee-coalition.org/about-us/leadership/index.html|title=Leadership|work=Amputee Coalition|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref>
